body: This is a "feature" in the same way that not being able to scrollback is a "feature". You need to buffer everything that has been outputted from the underlying process so that you can reflow it on resize.

issue.title: Implementation of scrollback
issue.body:
The `Grid<T>` is now a view into a region (I called it the 'active region') of a `VecDeque`. When new lines are added, they are pushed onto the back of the queue, and once the scrollback buffer is considered 'full', then old lines are popped off the front of the queue. This seems to work rather well since, unlike a `Vec`, elements don't need to be reshuffled around very often.

Of course, as discussed in #124 there are a few things that need to be fixed before I'd consider this 'ready':

- [x] configurable max scrollback length
- [ ] write new tests
- [x] fix existing `ref` tests
- [ ] measure performance impact (it seems fine but some numbers would be more reassuring)
- [x] fix out of bounds errors on resize

body: Since I wrote my comment there has been a lot of work on scrollback. I haven't looked at the details, but depending on how the scrollback buffer is implemented you could get reflow on resize at the same time. If, on the other hand, the scrollback buffer only buffers the "view" and not the real output from the pty I think "reflow on resize" is quite a big task to implement.
@jwilm Is or will be this issue fixed by new scrollback implementation (scrollback branch)?
I highly doubt it will be fixed by the new scrollback implementation. I don't think it would be a smart idea to delay scrollback for this feature.

issue.title: No Wrap Mode
issue.body:
I frequently run commands that have outputs which wrap text onto newlines (as we all do), the way we handle this today is the correct default behavior, but it would be neat to have the ability to active a "no wrap mode" where the arrow keys (h,j,k,l too) would scroll around the text. This would remove a very common pattern of rerunning the last command piped to `less -S`.

I understand this project is resistant to new features (for good reason), so I won't be offended if this is closed in the name of complexity. I do think this would be a relatively small complexity add if we are already thinking of adding modes as in #262, and #1017.

body: Would also love to have this! Using the scrollback branch at the moment, but this behavior is not implemented there either.
now that scrollback has been implemented (thanks btw!), this feature should be considered again.

@cauebs I believe the two issues are slightly different. My understanding is that #390 is about moving lines out of the scrollback buffer when the terminal size grows. This issue is about reflowing text horizontally and not chopping it off.
Yeah, these two issues are completely separate. #390 was actually implemented already, but this one still needs a resolution.

issue.title: X11: No redraw when resizing in tiling WM (xmonad)
issue.body:
Which operating system does the issue occur on?

ArchLinux
`Linux dev 4.19.4-arch1-1-ARCH #1 SMP PREEMPT Fri Nov 23 09:06:58 UTC 2018 x86_64 GNU/Linux`

My NVIDIA versions
```
lib32-nvidia-utils 415.22-1
nvidia 415.22-1
nvidia-settings 415.22-1
nvidia-utils 415.22-1
opencl-nvidia-beta 390.25-1
```

If on linux, are you using X11 or Wayland?
X11

-----

I've had this problem for a while now and I keep checking Alacritty to see if it's gone away. I can't seem to find any other issues that match this description exactly (several are close, though). Essentially, when an alacritty window gets resized, then the text that no longer fits in the new size does not get reflowed *and* once the window is put back in its original size then the old text is no longer visible and never gets redrawn.

I'm not actually sure which behavior alacritty even wants to do here (reflow or redraw) but I suspect at least one of those two behaviors is intended.

I've attached a gif showing the behavior. I can link to a higher resolution MP4 if that's desired or if more detail is needed please let me know.

![ezgif-4-2e6e4611a4d0](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/72143/49688005-9df92c00-fad9-11e8-934d-ff53268342f1.gif)

Notably, this also happens if I'm using i3wm.
